title: Acceleration of gravity on a different planet

content.question: On another planet, a ball is in free fall after being released from rest at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. A graph of the height of the ball above the planet’s surface as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is shown. The acceleration due to gravity on the planet is most nearly

choices.label: <math alttext="8 meters per second squared" overflow="scroll"><mtext> 8 m</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>
<math alttext="16 meters per second squared" overflow="scroll"><mtext>16 m</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>
<math alttext="20 meters per second squared" overflow="scroll"><mtext>20 m</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>
<math alttext="40 meters per second squared" overflow="scroll"><mtext>40 m</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="16 meters per second squared" overflow="scroll"><mtext>16 m</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
